title: How Can I Buy a Monkey?

steps.title: Check your state‚Äôs laws to be sure it‚Äôs legal.
steps.content: Check your state‚Äôs laws to be sure it‚Äôs legal. The laws vary from state to state, but most states won‚Äôt let you adopt a monkey or ape without a permit and proof of an enclosure big enough for the animal to live happily. You'll probably have to be running a rescue or research center of some sort; you're unlikely to be able to buy a monkey as a pet. Check out animal rights nonprofit Born Free USA‚Äôs website for an overview of different states‚Äô laws regarding the adoption of exotic animals, including monkeys and apes. You may also need a certain level of experience with the animal you wish to adopt before you‚Äôre granted a permit. For instance, if you want to adopt certain wild animals in Florida (including a variety of primates, such as chimps, baboons, and gibbons), you need to log 1000+ hours of caretaking work with the species you‚Äôre looking to adopt. steps.title: Research the type of monkey you want.
steps.content: Research the type of monkey you want. There are over 300 different types of monkeys, and they differ widely from one another. Do as much research as possible on the type of monkey you‚Äôre interested in adopting‚Äîincluding whether it‚Äôs legal to own such a monkey in your state. [4] X Research source Monkeys differ by size, cost, social habits, and more. Understand the needs of the monkey you‚Äôre looking to adopt and make sure you‚Äôre equipped to care for your new pet.

steps.title: Find a reputable breeder.
steps.content: Find a reputable breeder. Way easier said than done. The internet is full of black market and scammy breeder websites, so try asking a professional monkey handler or exotic veterinarian what they recommend. They‚Äôre sure to have a better understanding of the ins and outs of monkey ownership. Send an email to the primate handlers at your local zoo for their advice. Search for exotic veterinarians in your area and ask them what they recommend. (If there are no exotic vets in your area, you probably shouldn‚Äôt get a monkey.) Just be prepared for whoever you reach out to to disapprove of your decision to own a monkey. They may or may not be willing to help you, even if you have the proper licensing. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Monkeys are very social, cute, and entertaining.
steps.content: Monkeys are very social, cute, and entertaining. If you‚Äôre looking for a pet to spend a lot of time with, a monkey may fit the bill. Monkeys are social creatures by nature, and once your monkey bonds with you, it will want to follow you everywhere. [6] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source Monkeys can be a challenge to train, but they‚Äôre very intelligent creatures capable of doing complex tricks. [7] X Research source They‚Äôre endlessly fun to watch and hang out with. As a bonus, they live a long time compared to more traditional pets. It‚Äôs incredibly hard to lose a pet, but the typical monkey lives anywhere from 20 to 40 years, meaning you probably won‚Äôt have to say goodbye to your buddy for a while. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Adopting a monkey may fuel illegal wildlife trafficking.
steps.content: Adopting a monkey may fuel illegal wildlife trafficking. Illegal wildlife trafficking involves the harvesting and selling of wildlife and wildlife products for use in medicine or fashion, as food, as pets, and more. [9] X Trustworthy Source U.S. Customs and Border Protection Federal law enforcement agency responsible for monitoring U.S. borders, facilitating international trade, and upholding customs laws Go to source Adopting a monkey may foil conservation efforts by contributing to the illegal wildlife trade, which could contribute to primate species extinction and population decrease. steps.title: Monkeys are expensive to buy and take care of.
steps.content: Monkeys are expensive to buy and take care of. The cost likely varies depending on the type of monkey you‚Äôre looking for. A smaller monkey, like a capuchin, might cost under $10,000, while a larger ape, like a chimp, might cost upwards of $50,000. And, of course, you‚Äôll likely need that permit, which will cost money. [11] X Research source Even after buying your monkey, they‚Äôre costly to care for . Plus, your home insurance company may require an addendum for exotic animals, which can increase your policy limits.

steps.title: It‚Äôs difficult to adopt a monkey legally.
steps.content: It‚Äôs difficult to adopt a monkey legally. It‚Äôs illegal to adopt a potentially dangerous animal in most states, but exactly what that means shifts depending on the state. Even if your state allows the adoption of monkeys, the necessary permits may be difficult to attain and expensive. Since you need a permit to handle a monkey, this could make getting someone to pet-sit for you a bit of a nightmare, as they‚Äôd need to be an experienced monkey handler, too. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Monkeys require a lot of care.
steps.content: Monkeys require a lot of care. Monkeys are a lot like children, so if you‚Äôre not prepared to have a baby, you‚Äôre probably not prepared to have a monkey. They require lots of attention, as well as exercise and toys to keep them active and entertained. They also need regular time outdoors. They also require lots of space, which most houses aren't big enough to afford. [13] X Research source Unlike with a cat or dog, you can‚Äôt just leave a monkey unattended for hours on end, and they can‚Äôt be left home alone for extended periods of time. Also, unlike a cat or dog, you can't let a monkey roam free in your house. For that matter, most houses are too small to comfortably contain an adequate monkey enclosure, so unless you're running a monkey rescue, you probably don't have the space to care for a monkey. Guidelines look a little different for different species, but essentially, you‚Äôll need to make sure your enclosure is safe, clean, and large enough for your monkey to have plenty of space to move about it. [14] X Research source You‚Äôll need to find an exotic animal veterinarian before adopting your monkey, which can be a challenge if there‚Äôs not one in your area.

steps.title: Monkeys can sometimes pose health risks.
steps.content: Monkeys can sometimes pose health risks. Because monkeys and people are so closely related, disease-causing organisms, including bacteria, fungi, parasites, and viruses, are easily passed between them. For example, one of the most serious diseases monkeys may pass to humans is herpesvirus B. [15] X Research source This isn't much of a risk when it comes to monkeys bred in the United States, so if you're trying to open a monkey sanctuary, you may not have to worry about it. However, since monkeys are rarely permitted as pets in the country, it's likely you'd have to acquire your monkey through illegal means, usually by having it smuggled into the country, meaning your monkey is far more likely to carry diseases.

steps.title: Pet monkeys are difficult to train.
steps.content: Pet monkeys are difficult to train. Monkeys are smart, complicated creatures, which can make it difficult to train them if you don‚Äôt have a thorough understanding of primate behavior. [16] X Research source They can be stubborn and towheaded, making taming them a challenge. [17] X Research source Not only are they hard to train, but they‚Äôre also pretty messy, and it can be hard to train them to be neater. When it comes down to it, monkeys are wild animals, and they aren't really meant to live in a house.

steps.title: Older monkeys can be unpredictable and dangerous.
steps.content: Older monkeys can be unpredictable and dangerous. Baby monkeys can be cute and fun, but once they reach sexual maturity‚Äîaround 3 or 4 years of age‚Äîthey‚Äôre prone to more aggressive and unpredictable behavior. Even if your monkey bonded with you as a baby, it may become difficult or even dangerous to live with as an adult. [18] X Trustworthy Source National Geographic Website of the National Geographic Society Go to source Even if your monkey is affectionate and friendly with you, there‚Äôs no guarantee it won‚Äôt be scared or uncomfortable around other people, leaving them at risk of harm. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Because they live so long, you‚Äôll be committed to them for a while.
steps.content: Because they live so long, you‚Äôll be committed to them for a while. Monkeys can live to be anywhere from 20 to 40 years old. That‚Äôs a long time to care for a pet, especially one that‚Äôs as expensive and high-maintenance as a monkey. Before adopting a monkey (or any pet, for that matter), be sure you know how long you might be committed to their care. [20] X Research source

steps.title: You may need to get more than one monkey.
steps.content: You may need to get more than one monkey. Monkeys aren‚Äôt lone wolves, and they‚Äôll likely require a significant amount of your time. An undersocialized monkey may be more prone to biting and screaming‚Äîbehaviors that are difficult to manage. Some monkeys need to be a part of a hierarchy, meaning you may need to adopt 5 or 6 monkeys. You‚Äôll also likely need to understand the politics of that hierarchy yourself and treat the monkeys accordingly.

steps.title: The monkey may not bond with everyone in your life.
steps.content: The monkey may not bond with everyone in your life. Monkeys are social, but that doesn‚Äôt mean they bond with everyone or that they‚Äôll even tolerate everyone. It‚Äôs possible your monkey will only bond with a few people, making it difficult to develop new relationships if your monkey doesn‚Äôt take to the person.

steps.title: Domesticated monkeys often suffer psychological trauma.
steps.content: Domesticated monkeys often suffer psychological trauma. When it comes to monkeys, "taming" is often code for "breaking." Many domesticated monkeys suffer extreme trauma from being taken from their mothers at very young ages or from being trained by people with no experience with the animal. [21] X Research source As "cute" as a monkey in a sweater is, clothing can restrict a monkey's natural movements. Without freedom of movement, monkeys may become anxious and aggressive. Traumatized monkeys often develop anxious behaviors such as rocking, pacing, and overgrooming. While you might think a smiling monkey is a happy one, smiling is actually a defensive gesture for monkeys, indicating distress.

steps.title: ‚ÄúAdopt‚Äù a monkey at the zoo or another animal organization.
steps.content: ‚ÄúAdopt‚Äù a monkey at the zoo or another animal organization. Born Free USA and Wild Futures are two of many organizations that allow you to sponsor a monkey in a sanctuary. While it‚Äôs not the same as having the monkey yourself, a sanctuary surrounded by trained handlers and other primates is likely to be a safer, more fulfilling environment for the monkey, and your sponsorship will do long-term good for the protection of endangered or at-risk species. Adopting a sanctuary monkey often includes a personalized certificate of your adoption, a photo of ‚Äúyour‚Äù monkey, information about ‚Äúyour‚Äù monkey‚Äôs history, and regular news about your monkey‚Äôs well-being. You may also be able to see the monkey when the sanctuary is open to visitors, if you live near it. If you don't live nearby, you may have virtual access to your monkey online.

steps.title: Opt for another pet.
steps.content: Opt for another pet. There are loads of other animals who will be just as fun and affectionate (if not more so) as a monkey‚Äîand they‚Äôd likely be lower-maintenance and easier to obtain. steps.title: Probably not (and you probably can't, anyway).
steps.content: Probably not (and you probably can't, anyway). In conclusion, monkeys are not only difficult to acquire legally, they're best left where they belong: in the wild‚Äîor, barring that, in a big sanctuary run by monkey experts, where they have plenty of space to play and hang out with other monkeys. Monkeys are so cute and special, and it would be so great to have one to hang out with whenever you want, but unfortunately, it's just not in the monkey's best interest the vast majority of the time‚Äîand it's probably not in your best interest, either!
